Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network: Quantum Phenomena in Atomic Hydrogen Stabilized in Solid Molecular Hydrogen
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This Materials World Network project will be focus on two main thrusts: (i) further studies of H atoms in molecular H2 films as well as D atoms in D2 films at lower temperatures, and (ii) extension of the work on impurity-helium condensate samples to lower temperatures and higher concentrations. Techniques will be modified to attain higher concentrations of H and D atoms in an attempt to observe Bose-Einstein condensation (BEC) of H in H2 and Pauli paramagnetism in D and D2 films. The mm wave studies of H atoms at T < 1 K in thin and thick films of molecular H2 will be continued, with emphasis on careful temperature dependence measurements of the magnetization for samples prepared under different conditions in order to identify the cause of the non-Boltzmann behavior of the populations of the two lowest hyperfine states previously observed below 1 K. In addition a quartz microbalance will be utilized to test for superfluid behavior at low temperatures, a manifestation of BEC. A search will be made for changes in the Raman Spectrum associated with BEC. The ongoing research will include further studies of impurity-helium condensates containing hydrogen atoms, deuterium atoms or mixtures of H and D atoms in and on clusters of Kr and other noble gases. X band pulsed and CW ESR will be employed to study the magnetic relaxation behavior and the distribution of H and D atoms in and around the nanoclusters.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
Confirmation of the occurrence of Bose-Einstein condensation for H atoms moving through a solid molecular hydrogen crystal would be an important example of Bose-Einstein condensation in a periodic structure. Furthermore, mixed samples of H and D atoms contained in molecular matrices are excellent systems for the study of low temperature chemical reactions through the process of exchange quantum tunneling. Studies of impurity- helium condensates composed of assemblages of nanoclusters tie in nicely with studies of other forms of soft condensed matter. The impurity-helium condensates provide a means of storing large amounts of chemical energy which is released when the atoms combine to form molecules. This Materials World Network project clearly crosses the boundary between physics and chemistry and may provide valuable clues for practical energy storage systems. Further advances in millimeter wave technology being developed for ultralow temperature magnetic resonance will be useful in many other areas of science. The collaborative programs will benefit greatly from extended visits of graduate students, post docs and senior researchers between the partner laboratories.

This project is supported by the Condensed Matter Physics program and the Office of Special Programs in the Division of Materials Research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A collaborative project between Texas A&M University and Turku University (Finland) in the field of material science and engineering has been devoted for creating new materials with unique quantum properties. We have created high densities of hydrogen atoms in solid molecular hydrogen matrices and have studied tunneling chemical exchange reactions of D+HD→D2+H in solid D2 and HD matrices at temperatures down to 130 mK. The rates obtained for exchange reactions were independent of temperature in the temperature range studied (see Fig 1), providing evidence that another tunneling chemical reaction such as the exchange reaction H+H2→ H2+H, should also proceed in a solid H2 matrix at the lowest temperatures. This give an opportunity for H atoms to approach one another at a distance less than the de Broglie wavelength specified by quantum mechanics and to form a Bose–Einstein condensate at a very low temperature. For this situation, the wave functions associated with each of the atoms overlap with one another, leading to a single macroscopic wave function and resulting in superfluid behavior. The main tool in our investigations was a 128 GHz cryogenic electron spin resonance (ESR) spectrometer.

We also studied dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) for H and D atoms in solid films of molecular hydrogen isotopes (H2, HD, and D2). In the molecular hydrogen-deuterium films containing high concentrations of H and D atoms, by saturating the allowed ESR transitions a complete positive or negative nuclear polarizations of H atoms were achieved. A completely new effect involving the creation of a negative polarization of H atoms by applying a large microwave field to saturate the center of the H and D atom ESR spectrum was observed. This effect involved exchange interactions of H atoms in H-D2-H complexes formed as a result of exchange tunneling reactions in mixed H2-D2 solid films.  

Investigations of solid molecular tritium and hydrogen-tritium films were also carried out. Atomic tritium and hydrogen were formed in these films due to β–decay of radioactive tritium. Very high concentrations were achieved for atomic hydrogen (1?1020 cm-3) and atomic tritium (2?1020 cm-3) in 100 nm thick films. In these experiments an unexpected large broad signal with a maximum appeared at the center of ESR spectra (see Fig. 2). This broad peak may be result of exchange interactions of stabilized atoms in the regions of very high concentrations of atoms as was seen in semiconducting silica doped by phosphorus, where it was thought to be associated with the possible onset of metallic-like behavior.

The processes of H atom recombination were studied in the ensembles of molecular hydrogen-neon nanoclusters immersed in superfluid 4He. The nanoclusters form a porous aerogel-like structure inside superfluid 4He. It was found that H atoms from different nanoclusters could be transported toward each other through this structure due to exchange tunneling reactions and participate in the process of recombination as observed by ESR technique. The observed phenomenon opens up the possibility for a search for macroscopic collective quantum effects in the ensembles of percolated nanoclusters containing high concentrations of H atoms at ultralow temperatures accessible by a dilution refrigerator.

In our collaborative work on spin polarized hydrogen gas the Bose-Einstein condensation of magnons was achieved. Magnons are quantum particle associated with spin waves just as photons are associated with electromagnetic waves.
